[38;5;1m## 1. Add fast-vm repository into system ##[m(B

[root@examples-f26 ~]# 
curl -o /etc/yum.repos.d/fast-vm.repo https://copr.fedorainfracloud.org/coprs/ondrrejhome/fast-vm/repo/fedora-26/ondrejhome-fast-vm-fedora-26.repo

verage Speed   Time    Time     Time  Current

     0    242      0  0:00:01  0:00:01 --:--:--   242

[38;5;1m## 2. Install 'fast-vm' package ##[m(B

[root@examples-f26 ~]# 
dnf install fast-vm -q -y

[38;5;1m## To see detailed progress, remove the '-q' option. Process takes several minutes. ##[m(B

warning: /var/cache/dnf/ondrejhome-fast-vm-332054130bc904d2/packages/fast-vm-1.2.1-1.fc26.noarch.rpm: Header V3 RSA/SHA1 Signature, key ID ec5e8190: NOKEY
warning: /var/cache/dnf/updates-2854b3113b7a3c6c/packages/libvirt-client-3.2.1-6.fc26.x86_64.rpm: Header V3 RSA/SHA256 Signature, key ID 64dab85d: NOKEY

[38;5;1m## 3. Install 'libguestfs-tools-c' package to be able to use public fast-vm images ##[m(B

[root@examples-f26 ~]# 
dnf install libguestfs-tools-c -q -y

[38;5;1m## 4. Configure the fast-vm ##[m(B

[root@examples-f26 ~]# 
configure-fast-vm
[[38;5;6minf[m(B] ==>> fast-vm configuration script
You can run this script repeatedly and interrupt it with ctrl+c.

Script will always recheck all configuration options. fast-vm system configuration will be saved in /etc/fast-vm.conf.

[[38;5;1merr[m(B] libvirt daemon is not running or we cannot connect to it.
Ensure that libvirt service is running and that you can connect to it using command 'virsh --connect qemu:///system' and then re-run this configuration script.

[38;5;1m## If 'libvirtd.service' was not running you will receive above error. Just start service a re-run fast-vm configuration ##[m(B

[root@examples-f26 ~]# 
systemctl start libvirtd

[38;5;1m## 5. Configuration needs at minimum to know 'VG' that has some free space. Example below will use VG 'c7vg' and will dedicate '20GB' of space to fast-vm. ##
## To use default valued from configuration just hit [38;5;6m [ENTER] [m(B

[root@examples-f26 ~]# 
configure-fast-vm
[[38;5;6minf[m(B] ==>> fast-vm configuration script
You can run this script repeatedly and interrupt it with ctrl+c.
Script will always recheck all configuration options. fast-vm system configuration will be saved in /etc/fast-vm.conf.

[?] VG for LVM thin pool
 fast-vm is using LVM thin LV to store VM images and data.
 Available VGs on your systme are: 
   VG  Attr   VSize  VFree 
  f26 wz--n- 29.50g 24.37g

 On which existing VG should be this thin LV? 
[]: 
f
 [38;5;6m[ENTER][m(B

[?] LVM thin pool name
 Name the thin LV on which data would be stored.
 NOTE: This can be both 'name of existing thinpool LV' or 'name for a new one'.
 If LV with this name doesn't exists, it will get created by this setup. 
[fastvm-pool]: 
[38;5;6m[ENTER][m(B

[?] LVM thin pool size
 You can use units understood by LVM like M,G,T.
 NOTE: This applies only when thin LV doesn't exists yet. 
[50G]: 
G
 [38;5;6m[ENTER][m(B

[?] VM name prefix in libvirt
 Prefix is used in VM names and VM drive names. 
[fastvm-]: 
[38;5;6m[ENTER][m(B

[?] Users that want to use fast-vm must be members of following group.
 WARNING: if this group is different from 'libivrt' you would have to adjust libvirt configuration.
 Please check the fast-vm.conf(5) if setting this to something else than 'libvirt'. 
[libvirt]: 
[38;5;6m[ENTER][m(B

[?] Libvirt network (bridge) name
 This configuration will create a libvirt 
 network with this name providing NAT for VMs. 
[fastvm-nat]: 
[38;5;6m[ENTER][m(B

[?] Libvirt subnet number (192.168.XX.0/24) 
[22]: 
[38;5;6m[ENTER][m(B

[?] Directory in which to store VM notes 
[/var/tmp]: 
[38;5;6m[ENTER][m(B

[?] Only 'root' and 'owner' of VM should be able to delete VM through fast-vm?
 "yes" - only 'root' and 'owner' can delete VM
 "no" - anyone allowed to use fast-vm can delete VM (default in versions =< 0.9) 
[no]: 
[38;5;6m[ENTER][m(B

[[38;5;3mwrn[m(B] LV 'f26/fastvm-pool' not found
Following commands would be executed to create thin pool:
  lvcreate -n fastvm-pool -L 20G f26
  lvconvert --type thin-pool f26/fastvm-pool
[?] Create now? (y/n) 
y
 [38;5;6m[ENTER][m(B

[38;5;1m## 6. Verify that fast-vm is installed and configured properly by trying to list the VMs. You should receive no errors as in example below ##[m(B

[root@examples-f26 ~]# 
fast-vm list
VM# Image name      Status       Profile_name    Size( %used ) Notes
